div.aria-label: April 2 - Dr. Eagen's COVID-19 Update 14 News Post
div.p: Please read the update below. It is lengthy, so please make sure to read all the way to the bottom.
div.span:
I want to take this opportunity to provide you with a few key updates regarding the COVID-19 crisis and school district functions. The situation continues to evolve as we receive daily updates from Suffolk County, the Governor’s Office, and State Education Department.
The point that I want to emphasize more than any other is that today is about health, including mental health. It is important that we all continue to do what we can for ourselves and others to stay healthy. This is critical.
The most common question that I am continually asked is, “…how long do you think schools might be closed for?” At the time that this correspondence was prepared, the Governor had extended the closing of schools through Wednesday, April 15. However, the Governor indicated that he would continue to reevaluate every two weeks. Earlier this week, President Trump extended federal social distancing guidelines to April 30, so it is very likely that school closures will continue through April 30. However, we will need to wait and see.
As I previously mentioned, school districts have been directed to operate three distinct essential services while our schools are closed. They are:
• Continuity of learning
• Meals for students
• Childcare for first responders and healthcare workers
IMPORTANT: This past week, school districts were directed by the Governor’s Office to continue to provide remote instruction (continuity of learning) for students, meals for students, and childcare for essential workers “every … even if the district is scheduled to be on spring break during that time.” Additionally, we were directed to push back school elections until at least June 1, 2020. The school district has plans in motion to make sure that we continue all three of these three essential services.
CONTINUITY OF LEARNING
At this point, my faculty and administration are committed to providing for continuity of learning as best we can through this crisis, including the scheduled Spring Recess. This is not only a directive from the Governor and State Education Department, but we also have a moral obligation to meet the needs of our students to the greatest degree possible during this pandemic. The greater need here is that the crisis is projected to peak while we would have been out on Spring Recess. This is problematic for a variety of reasons. First, let’s be honest – we are not likely going anywhere anytime soon, as we are essentially quarantined to home. Above all else, I believe that it is critically important for adults and students to all be intellectually engaged over the coming weeks. We need to keep busy. This will prevent us all from focusing solely on just the pandemic. It will also help with social distancing and preventing us all from going completely “stir crazy.” An update will be provided in the coming days that will describe the continuity of learning that will be expected over the period that would have been our Spring Recess. You will receive more details specific to this topic very shortly.
MEALS for Students
With the help of Aramark (our food service vendor) and our bus drivers and driver assistants, we are now providing over 250 meals (breakfast and lunch - daily) for children in need in Kings Park! This service will continue through Spring Recess, and as long as we are physically able to perform this service through the crisis.
“Grab and Go” is occurring in the Kings Park High School main lobby daily, Monday – Friday, from 8:00 – 10:00 a.m. Students receive both breakfast AND lunch in one bag. The “Breakfast Bus” is now two buses, and they operate in the community daily during the same timeframe.
To all of our families in need: Local food pantries are available through Island Harvest and the Town of Smithtown.
Go to their website, https://www.islandharvest.org and search by zip code to find a location nearby. Please find below a listing of a few of the closest pantries to Kings Park.
Salvation Army - East Northport; 631-368-1170; 319 Clay Pitts Road, East Northport, NY 11731 (Tuesday and Thursday 10AM-3PM)
Manna Ministries; 631-334-1612; 782 Larkfield Road, East Northport, NY 11731 (Wednesday 6PM-8:30PM)
St. Francis of Assisi - St. Vincent de Paul; 631-651-2655; 29 North Gate Drive, Greenlawn, NY 11750 (Monday through Friday 9AM-3:30PM)
To those families that wish to contribute: If you would like to contribute towards those in need at this time, please refer to the Island Harvest website. You can volunteer or donate funds from the comfort of your own home if you so choose. https://www.islandharvest.org
Additionally, LI CARES has been able to make arrangements to dispatch mobile units as well, as a large number of local restaurants are looking to donate food. People can call (631) 582-FOOD. LI Cares needs volunteers at all our locations to help sort and pack food. They are accepting small groups (less than six), creating schedules to avoid overlapping and to keep people safe and comfortable. People can call (631) 582-FOOD.
I want to publically thank SEPTA. Members of SEPTA have been making donations to a “make-shift food pantry” that we have set up in the main lobby at Kings Park High School. Members of our community have found this source of food and other items to be very helpful, especially over weekends when the school district is not able to provide meals. Thank you!
CHILDCARE for first responders and healthcare workers
The Governor’s Office and Suffolk County are very concerned about being able to provide for childcare specific to first responders and healthcare workers during this crisis. Suffolk County has established a program through SCOPE Educational Services to provide childcare for the school-aged children of first responders and healthcare workers. Kings Park is a participating district in this plan. If you are a parent/guardian, you are a first responders or healthcare worker, and you are in need of childcare, please read the two documents posted to the school district website at:
https://www.kpcsd.org/apps/news/show_news.jsp?REC_ID=625732&id=0
You can register directly with SCOPE by following the instructions attached. Pending the proper inter-municipal agreement, it is likely that Northport will be the closest site to Kings Park. https://www.scopeonline.us/
Due to the postponement of school elections by the Governor until at least June 1, the April 7, 2020 Budget Adoption presentation has also been postponed. We will continue to work on developing the 2020-2021 school district budget once we receive more direction from the state.
In closing, thank you all for navigating these challenging times as best you can. We miss our students, and we can’t wait for this crisis to be over so that we can return to some degree of normalcy again. We continue to Apollo-13 these challenges. Right now health, including mental health, is the most important thing. We will get through this, together! No one does Family like Kings Park!
Be safe, and God bless,
Timothy T. Eagen, Ed.D.
Superintendent of Schools
Kings Park Central School District
